Jeſu forbid, that ſo handſom a young Gentleman, ſhou'd have as much deſpair in his Heart as Perſon— Marina, go and bid Isabel be ſure to mind what I told her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Madam.
Well done Mother, get as large a ſhare of the Sex as you can, I'll not ſtay to diſpute your Title.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: What don't you know me Sir. Amorous— Bleſs me, what not anſwer me?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: Too well Madam— I know you as the cauſe of all my ills, the glorious cauſe of my undoing.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Lord, my mind miſgave me when I heard that mournful Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs 'twas dull, unfit for Brides, and cou'd but dead your thoughts.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: But Sir Amorous, what is the real occaſion of this Sadneſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: Let me dye, Madam, if your Ladiſhip does not ridicule my ſufferings. Have you forgot what I told you laſt Night; that and a thouſand times more lyes heavy on my Heart to day; and unleſs you reſolve to ſee me dead, you muſt not marry Mr. Wilmore—

lg.l: He a Wretch inſenſible of all your Charms,
And who ſeeks his Happineſs in anothers Arms.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: He Lord, he's the Modeſteſt Gentleman; ſo Civil he never preſt for the leaſt Favour, no not for a Kiſs; and that you'l ſay's but a ſmall one; but when he cou'd not decently avoid it.

sp.speaker: Sir. Am.
sp.p: A Wretch, is it poſſible Madam, that the Tranſports of a Man, when alone, with ſo fine a Woman — Oh Madam! Were it but permitted me— But why do I vainly meditate on any thing but Death!

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Death, Heaven forbid: Indeed I am very ſorry, I was not acquainted with you, before things came to this extremity — But as to Mr. Wilmore, he is ſo baſhful, and ſo modeſt, Lord, you wou'd not believe any thing elſe in him.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: All that a Rival can ſay, will be ſuſpected: But ſay I clear'd it to you, what then ſhall be my reward?

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Indeed I ſhou'd be furiouſly angry to find him ſo cold only to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: If your Ladyſhip will let me wait upon you to the Garden, I'll clear the matter to you.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: DO you remember, our laſt Diſcourſe Belira?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Can I ever forget any thing where you'r concern'd.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Then I muſt tell you, I'm reſolved to Marry where I beſt can like, not for conveniency alone, 'tis ſinful, and you, and I, and all muſt live to dye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So godly, one wou'd think your Time were come: You have forgot ſure, Marina is to marry your Father.
sp.stage: Sir Amorous and Lady Young Love appear abſconding.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: She never will Belira, therefore if you have Loved, ſhew it in this only proof, I ever ask't, and let me marry her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How dare you think the queſtion, much leſs to ask it? I only live for you, in hopes of you; and when thoſe hopes are gone, I've done with life, the heavy load will not be worth the bearing, the very thought has looſn'd it, and I want pow'r to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: No Tears Belira, we will be always Friends, your Honour ſhall be ſafe, and you my chiefeſt care.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What can pay Love, but Love? Marinas Arms will make you cold to mine; nor can I ſtoop, to ſhare your hurt. O yet conſider! e're it be too late, think on the Wreck, the ruin of your Fortune, the flowing Tides of Poverty, that ruins all it covers; and laſtly, think on an unhappy Wretch, whoſe only fault is deſperate Love of you.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I've thought on all, and nicely weighed the Senſe; the conſequence is this, I Love Marina, and rather than not marry her, wou'd be undone; therefore if you can ſave me 'twill be Noble, and like the Love you promiſed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What Generoſity canſt thou hope to find, where only injuries are given? what ſuffering, tame, deluded Monſter doſt thou think me? My Wrongs have waked that Rage, which Wonder had be-calm'd, and I am now prepared to daſh thy hopes, and prove thee Traytor to thy Vows and me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Be wiſe Belira! We live not now in thoſe Romantick conſtant days, where their firſt Miſtreſs was their laſt. I lik'd you once, and ſtill eſteem you, but Vows that are made in Love, are writ in ſand: It's impoſſible to recal a Lovers Heart, when once 'tis made a Preſent to another; ſhou'd it return, 'twou'd ſooner Love a third.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou needſt not ſeek for Arguments to kill my Hopes; thus I blow them from me: Farewel for ever, both to thy Love and them; thou haſt Lov'd me little, but thou knowſt me leſs: Vengeance is due to thy miſtake; I only live to wiſh, and hope to ſee it take your Minion: Love her as long as you are uſed to Love a Woman, and then let want of Wealth and Liberty purſue you: Be poorly Wretched, and Wretched Poor; and may you hate the cauſe as bad as I do Curſe for her ſake, the very name of Woman; yet think on me and ſigh for ſuch a Friend — But may no Friend be found, till ſcorned at home thou ſeekeſt abroad, ſome Wretched Death unknown.
sp.stage: Going to Lady Young Love, Sir Amorous meets her.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: What have I heard and ſeen Belira? Is it poſſible it ſhou'd be you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Villain, haſt thou betray'd me— Madam, I warn you from that Traytor Wilmore,

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmore, I am ſorry I was ſo long your pretence, Sir Amorous. This diſcovery has done me mighty Service, and I am ſorry I cannot expreſs my Gratitude to you.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I have too juſtly offended your Ladyſhip, ever to hope Forgiveneſs: I only beg your Anger may not fall upon Marina, ſhe's an Innocent cauſe.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: The Age is quite Debauch'd, Jeſu! who ſhall we truſt after this? Belira naught, and with modeſt Mr. Wilmore, I am in ſuch amaze, I can't recover my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What's the matter? I met Belira in a mighty rage, ſhe ran to this Ladies Chamber with a drawn Sword? 'twas lucky I was in the way, elſe ſhe had murdered her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhan't recover the fright this month! Mr. Wildman has ſaved my life.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: He ſhall always command mine for it, but what's become of her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: When ſhe ſaw her ſelf Defeated, ſhe ſent for a Chair, and went away in it; I have not yet troubled my ſelf to know where.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: No 'tis no matter, ſince my Houſe is rid of her. I ſhall take care who I entertain a good opinion of again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prithee Wilmore, no Chagrin. This was my Plot, I durſt not truſt thee with it; and therefore adviſed thee to meet her in the Garden, I knew thy ſoft Nature, wou'd not ſuffer thee, to Expoſe an ill Woman, tho' to make thy ſelf happy in a good.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: If you had, 'twou'd never have come to this; my Pity is due to an unhappy Woman, who had never bin ſuch, if She had not known me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You'l make Marina Jealous,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I hope not, ſhe wou'd not have me Barbarous:

sp.speaker: Sir Ruſ.
sp.p: Where are ye all? Before George the Canonical hour will be paſt; yonders the other Young Gentlewoman gone away Diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Wild.
Sir Ruſ.
sp.p: Be-gad, I don't believe a word of this: You are not of his mind Sweet-heart, Mr. Prieſt-Craft is ready to ſpoil your ſport Sir, and begin ours.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Indeed Sir Amorous, you have convinc'd me of the reality of your Paſſion, and were it not for the talk of the Town, you ſhou'd find me, not ſo inſenſible as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: Let me be nothing Madam, if this unexpected Marriage will not put them all out of Countenance, and baulk their Spleen; they are prepared by Mr. Wilmore's concern for your Daughter, to laugh at your Ladyſhip. No Wedding— Let me expire, if it wou'd not be a good way, to prevent his refuſal by yours, and before he asks you to make him happy with Marina, to make me ſo in your ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: 'Twere a good Jeſt indeed, I think we muſt not ſpoil the Conceit—But then, Sir Amorous, will you be conſtant?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: As your own Charms, which can never admit of a Decay.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Amorous, I have Compaſſion upon your Sufferings, and a juſt Reſentment of Mr. Wilmore's Ingratitude: Therefore, Sir Amorous—but Lord! what was I going to ſay?—Jeſu!— will not you think me quickly won?—But indeed, my Charity to you is the chief Inducement; therefore to morrow, Sir Amorous, if you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: To morrow will not prevent Mr. Wilmore: Give me leave to declare my Happineſs, and to hope you will immediately confirm it within.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Lard, Sir Amorous, you overcome me every way; I leave it to your Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruſ.
sp.p: Before George, not I. Good Mr. Son, no coguing nor diſſembling with me: I love the Lady my ſelf, and have her I will, or ſome ſhall ſmart for it. My Lady Young Love, here's Felony, Conſpiracy, and Treaſon againſt you; they would cheat me of my Wife, and you of your Husband.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: That they will hardly be able to do; I have made my Choice, Sir Amorous can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruſ.
sp.p: Hey day! Here's fine juggling indeed! Before George, I don't underſtand theſe London Contrivances. Shall I have your Daughter?

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Sir Amorous, you rule me. Marina, I have too long, won by Bellaria's Pretences, deny'd you the Affection of a Mother; but I'll make amends for all, and leave you the Liberty of your Choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruſ.
sp.p: Nay then, before George, 'tis ſtill well enough— Give me thy Hand, ſweet Miſtris, 'tis a Match, Bedad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am afraid, Sir, you'll find me good for little, but to bring the Addition of Jealouſie to the reſt of your Diſtempers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruſ.
sp.p: That is in plain Engliſh, Madam, that you wou'd make me a Cuckold—Wou'd you ſo?—Nay, like enough Bedad— Your Eyes have a plaguy Lear that way—Hey! [calls within there] Bid Ralph ſaddle the Horſes, and bring my Boots; I'll not ſtay to ſee the end on't.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No matter, let him go; as I take it, he has Sign'd. Wilmore, thou haſt nothing to do now, but to make thy Claim.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I have ſo true a Senſe of my Villany to this Lady, that I dare not addreſs for Pardon, much more the unvaluable Bleſſing of her Daughter.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: Sir Amorous has prevail'd for you, Sir. I forgive you, and have left Marina the Liberty of her Choice. But might I perſwade her, it ſhou'd not be Belira's Lover, he has too many Faults.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll take them all upon my ſelf; and if your Ladyſhip would conſent, I ſhould not think my ſelf unhappy with Mr. Wilmore.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Twill be generous, like your ſelf, Madam; and ſhew the Town, the little Concern you have for Mr. Wilmore.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: Let me expire, Madam, if I can ceaſe my Intreaties.

sp.speaker: L. Y. L.
sp.p: You command me, Sir Amorous. Take her, Mr. Wilmore; and if poſſible, make amends for your Faults to me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: This Goodneſs confounds me more—My whole Life ſhall be one conſtant Study to deſerve your Generoſity, and Marina's Kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why ſo? matters are brought to Perfection. I find I am a Maſter in the Art. But, Begad, Pimping here, I have ruin'd my own Affairs with Orinda. Will ſhe not be at the Wedding?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She keeps her Bed very ill, and has ſent an Excuſe; but I believe, Belira's Abſence will be the beſt Spell to draw her thence.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That ſhall be my buſineſs, after the Chaplain has done his: I'll viſit, and perſwade her to come and wiſh you Joy.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I am impatient till you have the occaſion. Sir Amorous, lead the way with your Bride.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I think Fortune has not one other Trick to diſappoint you with; but 'tis beſt to take her when ſhe's obliging, for ſuch all People that are going to be married think her.

lg.l: But Time will ſhew the Cheat, and you ſhall find
The Goddeſs is as fickle as ſhe's kind.

div.p: HAles's Contemplations in three Parts, the third Part never before Printed; to which is added his Life, by Gilbert Lord Biſhop of Sarum.

The whole Works of that Excellent Practical Phyſitian, Dr. Thomas Sydenham; wherein, not only the Hiſtory and Cure of Acute Diſeaſes are Treated of, after a new and Accurate Method, but alſo the ſhorteſt and ſafeſt way of Curing moſt Chronical Diſeaſes. Tranſlated from the Original Latin; by John Pechey, at the Colledge of Phyſitians.
Mrs. Behns Novels, are this day Publiſhed.
All three are Sold by R. Wellington at the Lute in St. Paul's Church-yard.

THE Artificial Clock-maker. A Treatiſe of Watch, and Clock-work: Wherein the Art of Calculating Numbers for moſt ſorts of Movements, is explained to the capacity of the Unlearned. Alſo the Hiſtory of Clock-work, both Ancient and Modern. With other uſeful matters never before Publiſhed. By W. D. M. A. Printed for James Knapton at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-Yard, 1696.
